From: "sonekazuo" <sonekazuo@...>
Subject: Reactor object and constant-pressure process
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=109697555; y=OUMVXyxu7n9ibSO9M6BG6VvjtT5gucVgx6SLbRnTB0axnfiW
X-Yahoo-Profile: sonekazuo
X-eGroups-Approved-By: dggoodwin <dgoodwin@...> via web; 08 Jun 2005 23:47:43 -0000

Professor Goodwin,
I was going through cantera v1.5.5r4 and c++ examples, and found that
in kinematics examples 1 & 2, a relatively large volume is used to
model constant-pressure process.  I read more detailed comments in
Reactor.h file, and now I'm wondering in the 1-dimensional flame
examples (stflame1.py, npflame1.py) what is done to integrate chemical
source terms for 1-d similarity equations.  Do you use the same
large-volume strategy or is there any derived class from Reactor class
that models constant-pressure process?  I tried to find a clue in
StagnationFlow.py and onedim.py, but could tell what exactly is done
in the code.  Thank you very much in advance,
Kazuo Sone
